7.98.text:
I'd like to tell you about someone I met
in March, 2011.

16.05.text:
If she stood up, she would have been
about five feet tall,

20.15.text: but she weighed only forty pounds.

23.44.text:
She had a beak like a parrot,
and venom like a snake,

27.33.text: and ink like an old-fashioned pen.

30.25.text: She could change color and shape,

32.30.text:
and pour her boneless body
through an opening the size of a walnut.

37.81.text: Athena was a giant Pacific octopus.

43.01.text: I met her at the New England Aquarium,

45.45.text:
and her keeper
pulled off the lid to her tank.

49.14.text:
She turned red with excitement,
and slid over to meet me,

52.73.text:
and her eye swiveled in its socket
and locked into mine.

58.64.text:
I plunged my hands and arms
into the 47-degree water,

64.74.text:
and her eight arms
came boiling up to meet mine.

69.02.text:
Now, an octopus can taste
with all its skin, including the eyelids,

73.56.text:
but this sense is most
exquisitely developed in the suckers.

77.75.text:
And so, soon, I had the pleasure
of having the skin of my hands and arms

84.07.text:
covered with dozens
of her beautiful, wide, strong suckers,

93.91.text:
Later, I realized that not everyone
would like this.

99.96.text:
If a person had begun tasting me
so early in our relationship,

105.78.text:
And, boy, it was cold!
And yes, it was slimy.

109.97.text:
And then, there was the matter of all
those hickeys to explain to my husband

116.63.text:
But never was I for a moment afraid,
and neither was Athena.

124.10.text: Because she'd let me touch her head,

126.63.text:
and she hadn't let a stranger
touch her head before.

130.30.text:
And beneath my touch,
her skin turned white,

134.70.text:
the color, I later learned,
of a relaxed octopus.

141.65.text:
because, despite all of the millions
of years of evolution

148.53.text:
despite the fact that she
was a marine invertebrate,

152.33.text:
I felt very strongly that Athena was just
as curious about me as I was about her.

161.12.text:
Somehow, across half a billion years
of evolution,

165.78.text: we had had a meeting of the minds.

169.98.text:
Now, speaking about animals
of any kind having a mind

172.81.text:
makes some philosophers
and scientists nervous.

177.19.text:
But that's exactly what I want
to talk with you about,

180.31.text:
the overwhelming evidence that animals
across a wide variety of species

186.75.text:
do think, and feel,
and experience consciousness.

192.68.text:
Now, I'm not a scientist
or philosopher. I'm a writer.

195.97.text:
And I know what I've learned
from interviews and from reading

200.85.text:
and from fieldwork with animals,
both captive and wild.

205.23.text:
My first book talks a little
about Jane Goodall's work.

210.76.text:
She's very famous for her studies
of chimpanzees at Gombe,

216.38.text:
and today she's the most
well-known scientist in the world.

221.76.text:
But when she started out,
no one wanted to publish her work,

226.16.text: because she named her study animals,

230.39.text: instead of numbering them like rocks.

233.72.text:
But her findings were too important
to be ignored,

237.44.text:
and she found that chimpanzees
not only have minds,

240.57.text: but that their minds are so like ours.

247.48.text:
They develop friendships.
They use and make tools.

252.81.text:
They even fashion little sticks with which
to fish out termites from termite mounds.

257.98.text:
They create sponges from leaves
which they crumple,

262.34.text: and they can jam it into holes

264.03.text:
and withdraw liquids
that they want to get.

266.29.text:
They even make clubs
with which to hit other chimpanzees.

271.23.text:
The fact that they use
and make tools shows also

275.55.text:
that chimps aren't just living
in the eternal present.

282.04.text:
and they also imagine the minds
of other chimpanzees.

291.63.text: they even sneak off for illicit sex.

295.44.text:
The fact that their minds are so like ours
shouldn't really surprise us,

299.81.text:
because we share 99% of our
genetic material with a chimpanzee.

304.01.text:
You can get a blood transfusion
from a chimpanzee.

307.30.text:
In fact, even look at chimpanzees
and they might remind you,

310.19.text:
every once in a while, of that guy
you dated in college. (Laughter)

314.01.text:
But what about animals
that aren't so like us?

317.90.text: Why can't they have minds too?

320.95.text: Because their brains are too small?

323.21.text:
Well, anything can be miniaturized.
Look at computers.

326.56.text:
They used to take up a whole room,
and now they fit in your pocket.

333.54.text: Well, you don't need language to think.

336.20.text:
Despite what some linguists
might tell you,

338.98.text:
there are people out there thinking
very, very well without words.

343.77.text:
And one of them
is my friend Temple Grandin.

345.89.text:
I wrote a book about her 
for young readers.

348.53.text:
She's quite famous.
You may have heard of her.

351.54.text:
She creates humane designs,
including pens and even slaughterhouses

356.35.text:
that are meant to ease the pain
and fear of farm animals

360.82.text: that we use for milk, meat, and eggs.

364.87.text:
She has authored a dozen books,
she has written hundreds of articles,

369.25.text:
she's a college professor,
but because she has autism,

374.65.text: words did not come easily to her.

377.82.text:
In fact, she didn't speak
until she was aged six,

381.67.text:
and to this day,
she does not think in words.

385.87.text:
She'll tell you,
she thinks entirely in pictures.

392.54.text: So, you do not need language to think.

397.61.text:
What about tool use? That was a Rubicon
that supposedly animals couldn't cross.

403.75.text:
Well, we know that Jane Goodall's chimps
crossed that easily,

408.50.text: but in fact, lots of animals use tools.

412.75.text:
My favorite is a kind of baboon
called a mandrill.

415.84.text: He creates little q-tips from twigs,

418.91.text:
which he uses to cleanse ears 
and toenails. I think that's great.

424.37.text:
But let's leave our fellow mammals
aside for a moment.

429.08.text:
They're more closely related to dinosaurs
than they are to human beings,

434.58.text: and yet, they are champion tool users.

438.53.text:
There are some crows in Japan
that you may have heard about.

441.94.text:
They love to open nuts
and get the tasty meats,

445.40.text:
but sometimes, the nuts
are too hard to crack.

448.40.text: So, here's what they're doing in Japan:

450.38.text:
they fly to a traffic intersection,
they wait till the light turns red,

455.46.text:
and then, they put the nut down
in front of the cars.

459.65.text:
When the light turns green,
they open the nuts for them.

463.40.text:
And they're so smart that they actually
wait till the light again turns red,

468.13.text:
so they go pick up the nutmeats.
How smart is that?

472.48.text:
Every yardstick
that we have tried to use to show

475.39.text:
that, "Oh, animals can't think and we can"
has come up short.

481.06.text:
This is supposed to test
for self-awareness,

486.77.text:
So, you look at the mirror,
you recognize your reflexion,

491.26.text:
And we know this because, if you put
a dot of paint on that chimp's head,

495.14.text:
she'll look in the mirror and touch
her own finger to her face,

499.85.text: but a gorilla won't. And why is that?

503.55.text:
Not because they don't have 
self-awareness.

506.75.text:
It's because for a gorilla to look into
someone's face directly, that's a threat.

512.92.text:
It's not that they don't have
self-awareness.

515.54.text: It's because the gorilla is being polite.

519.25.text:
Another Rubicon, of course, was language.
People said only people have language.

524.29.text:
Well, that's not really true.
Just ask a parrot.

528.76.text: They might respond in plain English.

530.75.text:
Now, it's true that parrots love
to mimic sounds,

535.61.text:
There's one parrot I heard about,
who liked to watch TV,

539.54.text:
and all of a sudden,
began incessantly asking:

541.91.text:
"Does Hammacher Schlemmer
have a toll-free number?"

547.97.text:
But there are other parrots who know
and mean what they're saying,

553.35.text:
and one of them was Alex, 
the African grey.

557.16.text:
He lived with Dr. Irene Pepperberg,
who was his trainer, and researcher.

562.35.text: She taught him more than 100 words,

564.88.text:
but she did this not to prove
that animals could use language,

568.05.text:
but to use those words as a probe
to look inside the mind of a bird,

575.73.text:
One thing he understood quite well
was concepts of color and shape.

581.62.text:
She would ask him, holding out
a tray of objects, "What color, Alex?"

585.85.text:
And he'd say, "Gr-een",
or red, or whatever color it was.

589.62.text:
She also learned that parrots
can count, and add.

594.92.text:
But some of the most exciting insights
came when he spontaneously voiced

600.70.text: what was in his little birdy mind.

603.30.text:
And one of those moments happened
when she brought him home

606.06.text:
from the laboratory for the first time
to her house.

610.19.text:
It was night, and he looked out
her picture window,

614.12.text:
and saw for the first time
in his life an owl.

618.82.text:
And he began to scream,
"Wanna go back! Wanna go back!"

623.30.text:
He wanted to go back to the lab
because he knew, thanks to instincts

629.89.text:
as old as the ancestors
of parrots and the ancestors of owls,

637.39.text:
And he was telling us about this
ancient instinct in the English language,

642.94.text:
which he had learned
at a 21st-century university laboratory.

653.44.text:
Well, what about those animals
that don't speak to us in English?

658.03.text:
I want to talk to you about how I got
an insight into the mind of a creature

663.07.text:
that most people don't even think of
as having a mind: an electric eel.

668.79.text:
Now, I've met electric eels in the Amazon,
where they live wild, they're fish.

672.99.text:
But the one I want
to talk to you about today

675.09.text: lives at the New England Aquarium.

677.00.text:
You should go. 
You would love this exhibit.

679.16.text:
You'd love the whole aquarium,
but particularly the eels are great.

682.47.text:
Not only are they, as you can see,
very attractive animals -

687.06.text:
- but they've got this great exhibit
where you can actually see

692.13.text: the eel using his shocking powers.

695.19.text:
So, what they've done
is they've set up a voltmeter

698.67.text:
which goes off and flashes
when the eel is using his electricity

703.47.text: to locate and then stun prey.

707.13.text:
So, I was watching this eel
with Scott Dowd,

710.43.text:
the senior aquarist
for the freshwater gallery,

713.73.text:
and the eel was just sitting
on the bottom of the tank.

717.89.text:
He had a blank expression on his face,
and Scott confirmed that this electric eel

727.15.text:
You can probably tell that Scott and I
are pretty avid fish watchers,

730.55.text:
because we're standing there
in rapt attention,

733.08.text:
watching an electric eel to sleep.
(Laughter)

736.25.text:
But that's when it happened:
the voltmeter suddenly went off.

742.55.text:
I said to Scott, "What's happening?
I thought he was asleep."

750.68.text:
And we looked at each other, and we knew
right then the eel was dreaming.

757.54.text:
We've all seen our pets dream:
your dog's paws will twitch,

761.34.text:
or your cat's ears will move, and maybe
the cat is chasing a mouse,

765.43.text:
and maybe the dog
is dreaming of chasing a ball.

768.50.text:
But what do you think
electric eels dream about?

775.24.text:
Now, I don't know for sure,
but I would venture to guess

778.75.text:
that the eel on exhibit,
who they called Mittens,

782.38.text:
probably has slightly different dreams
from the eel behind the scenes,

789.34.text:
And that's because they have
very different personalities.

792.82.text:
Thor, the one behind the scenes,
is actually much more outgoing;

796.62.text:
once quite literally,
when it jumped out of its tank,

799.72.text:
with bad consequences to the fish
living in the adjacent tank.

804.88.text:
But there hasn't been
a lot of work done on fish personality.

808.31.text:
Interestingly though, there has been
work done, a lot of it and intriguing,

816.38.text:
and the person who has done
the most of that is Dr. Jeniffer Mather.

821.95.text:
And I had the great joy
and the privilege of working with her

826.35.text:
in a team of octopus experts, this summer,
off Maria, which is in French Polynesia,

832.18.text:
studying wild octopuses there,
the Pacific day octopus.

836.40.text:
Among the things 
that we did in our studies

839.08.text:
was administer personality tests
to wild octopuses.

848.74.text:
that octopuses have
quite distinct personalities,

851.33.text:
and this is often reflected 
in their names.

853.93.text:
In Seattle Aquarium,
they had one named Emily Dickinson,

857.82.text: because she was so shy she never came out.

860.14.text:
They eventually had to release her
into the Sound.

862.84.text: And then, there was Leisure Suit Larry,

865.59.text:
the octopus whose arms
were always all over you,

868.59.text:
and you'd peel one off
and two more would come on. (Laughter).

874.87.text:
and she was constantly dismantling
everything in her tank.

880.19.text:
Octopuses actually
really enjoy manipulating objects,

884.00.text: so much so that there's actually

887.15.text:
an octopus enrichment handbook
for aquaria,

891.16.text: to help you keep your octopus occupied.

896.12.text:
They suggest that you give them
Mr. Potato Head to play with,

901.17.text:
the same toys your child
might play with at home, or LEGOs.

905.55.text:
But at the New England Aquarium,
we had, happily, an engineer and inventor

911.08.text: from the Arthur D. Little Corporation.

913.40.text:
That's what we needed to come up
with a design interesting enough

917.38.text: to occupy the intellect of our octopuses.

920.67.text:
And what Wilson Menashi designed
was a series of boxes,

925.26.text:
and you'd put one inside the other,
inside the other,

927.76.text: and each box had a different lock.

930.98.text: Inside the first box, you had a crab,

934.72.text:
which the octopus could see,
since the boxes were clear.

938.17.text:
And the octopuses learned to unlock
every single one of those boxes

948.01.text:
some octopuses used
different techniques from others.

954.56.text:
and she was in a real hurry one day
to get to her crab.

958.48.text:
So, instead of unlocking the boxes,
which she knew how to do,

963.85.text:
She created a tiny crack, but she could
flow her arm right inside there,

970.98.text: Not much later, Truman got the boxes.

973.72.text:
He'd learned how to unlock them,
but one day, he was particularly excited

977.80.text:
because Bill Murphy, who's the keeper,
put two different crabs in there,

986.13.text:
So, what did he do?
He didn't bother with the locks.

989.31.text: He flowed his entire body into the cube.

995.37.text: And what you got was an octopus in a box.

1001.98.text:
The fact that they play
with toys and puzzles

1005.34.text:
shows that octopuses are so like us
in very moving ways,

1010.78.text:
considering that three-fifths
of their neurons are in their arms,

1015.81.text: But it makes it even more amazing,

1018.38.text:
the things that we share
with these animals.

1022.59.text:
And this has been recognized
in a document called

1029.58.text: which says that humans are not unique.

1033.28.text:
A series of different neuroscientists
worked on this to state

1037.89.text:
that humans aren't the only ones
who have the neural substrate

1044.22.text:
They specifically mention octopuses
in this document.

1048.13.text:
Well, at the New England Aquarium,
I've had the joy

1050.55.text: of meeting a number of octopuses,

1052.87.text:
and after Athena died of old age,
I met her successor, Octavia.

1059.02.text:
And with Wilson Menashi,
every Wednesday I would visit her,

1064.31.text: for a year, and she knew us.

1067.16.text:
She would float to the top, look at us,
play with us, touch us with her suckers,

1073.04.text:
until, after a year, she laid eggs,
and everything changed.

1078.74.text:
They lay eggs at the end of their lives,
and it's such an important event

1082.58.text: that they don't leave those eggs.

1084.72.text:
They guard them, they fluff them,
they clean them,

1088.60.text:
and they won't have anything
to do with you.

1091.53.text: She didn't even look at us.

1093.56.text:
We would feed her
on the end of a grabber,

1099.09.text:
And after ten months
of tending these infertile eggs,

1104.86.text:
She was at the end of her life,
she had an eye infection,

1108.37.text:
and Bill Murphy, her keeper, decided
it was time to move her behind the scenes.

1114.08.text:
So, we asked a volunteer
to try to urge her into a bucket,

1116.88.text:
so she could be moved,
and she wouldn't go in.

1121.23.text:
But the minute she touched and tasted
her old friend, her keeper, Bill,

1127.91.text:
even though he hadn't touched her
in ten months,

1131.83.text:
she went right into that bucket,
and was transferred to the new tank.

1137.12.text:
And the next Wednesday,
Wilson and I went to visit her.

1141.26.text:
We had not touched her,
she had not looked at us for ten months,

1147.37.text:
but the minute when we moved the top
of the tank, up she came to greet us,

1151.87.text:
looking us in the face,
and kissing us with her suckers.

1156.51.text:
She remembered us after all,
even though she was old,

1160.92.text: and she was tired, and she was near death.

1165.78.text:
I don't know what the octopuses
think of me,

1169.18.text: what I meant to them is not known to me,

1173.32.text: but I can tell you what they meant to me.

1179.17.text:
because they gave me
the most wonderful gift:

1182.75.text: a deeper understanding of what it means

1186.86.text: to think, to feel, and to know.
